summary.grammarTip:
The Nominativ case is the 'subject' case in German. It tells you who or what is performing the action in a sentence. To find the nominative, you can ask 'Wer?' (Who?) or 'Was?' (What?).

Articles in Nominativ

The basic forms of the articles are used in the nominative case.

GenderDefinite Article (the)Indefinite Article (a/an)
Masculine (m)derein
Feminine (f)dieeine
Neuter (n)dasein
Pluraldiekeine (no)

Adjective Endings in Nominativ

When an adjective comes before a noun, its ending changes.

with Definite Articlewith Indefinite Article
Masculineder gro√üe Hundein gro√üer Hund
Femininedie kleine Katzeeine kleine Katze
Neuterdas neue Autoein neues Auto
Pluraldie alten B√ºcherkeine alten B√ºcher

Verbs using Nominativ

Some verbs use the nominative case for both the subject and the object of the sentence. The most common ones are:

  • sein (to be): Er ist ein guter Lehrer.
  • werden (to become): Sie wird eine ber√ºhmte √Ñrztin.
  • bleiben (to remain): Er bleibt ein treuer Freund.
  • hei√üen (to be called): Ich hei√üe Alex.
